title: SHM - claim about maximum kinetic energy

content.prompt: A student observes a block attached to a spring undergo simple harmonic motion. The student claims that a block with a smaller mass attached to the same spring and oscillating with a smaller amplitude could have the same maximum kinetic energy as the original block. Is the studentâ€™s claim correct? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because the less massive block will have a greater average speed.
Yes, because even though the magnitude of the average force exerted on the block decreases, the less massive block requires less force to achieve the same acceleration.
No, because the less massive block will have less kinetic energy as the original block no matter what the amplitude is.
No, because changing the amplitude of the oscillation changes the initial potential energy, which is equal to the maximum kinetic energy of the block.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
